newsitem.title: USA: Finish Line April same-store sales up.
newsitem.headline: Finish Line April same-store sales up.

text.p: Finish Line Inc said Thursday its same store sales for the four-week period ended May 3 increased 1.8 percent.
The company reported same-store sales for the five week period ended April 5 fell 1.7 percent.
The numbers compare with same-store sales increases of 22.5 percent and 2.7 percent for April and May 1996, respectively.

"Slowness in certain men's and youth footwear departments were primarily responsible for the sluggish same-store sales in March and April," Alan Cohen, president and chief executive of Finish Line, said in a statement.
Total sales for the nine weeks ended May 3 were $62.54 million, a 23.1 percent increase from the $50.79 million reported last year, Finish Line said.
The company said product margins improved during the 1997 nine-week period, and per square foot inventory levels at May 3, 1997 were about 12 to 14 percent less than last year.

"The overall sluggish same-store sales can be related to consumer price resistance and less than robust sell-throughs on some new product introductions," Cohen said, adding activewear sales were also slow.
"We are looking for new footwear product introductions in the men's and youth departments scheduled for May through Back-to-School to help sales rebound in these areas," Cohen said.
